content.webTitle: Poem of the week: The Oy of the Poyem by Zohar Atkins

fields.headline: Poem of the week: The Oy of the Poyem by Zohar Atkins
fields.bodyText: The Oy of the Poyem: 28 Exercises in non-Mastery Click here for 29 reasons you are not not Mark Ruffalo. Click here for 6 proofs Buzzfeed is a distraction from the Buzzfeed as such. Click next to receive yourself as a coupon. Click Play Now to become forever. Click Incognito Mode to avoid the paywall, discover 10 myths you thought were facts. If the font ain’t Calypso, switch to Reality. If Reality ain’t high definition, petition your senator here. Each day, thousands of innocents lack yoghurt, political will, and courage to wear bright clothing. Coincidence? Each second you give to thinking will be matched by 30 minutes of callousness, regret, and avoidance. Click here to short your cynicism, make millions in emerging emotional markets. In the long-run, even mavericks fall on one side of the fence, wondering why they didn’t learn Esperanto. In the short-run we are all unborn. ‘That wasn’t 28.’ ‘Nu? So it wasn’t 28.’ Living up to his first name, Zohar Atkins is a rabbi and theologian, and a poet who can rhyme “mystical” with “listicle”. His first collection, Nineveh, takes delight in bringing disciplines and dictions together to interrogate history and each other. Incantation and instruction, meditation techniques and the social media, meet in this week’s poem, which takes the shape of a parodic listicle. An informal Yiddish idiom adds homeliness and an ironical shrug. Let’s begin with the title, which puts the “oy” in “poyem”. David Robson contends that “oy” is a “Goy proof” word (questionable, I think. No word is anyone-proof!) He explains that “a thousand Chasidic oys equal one extended Buddhist “Omm…” – a nice listicle-style aphorism in the spirt of Akins’s poem, adding that “A single ‘oy’ does justice to almost any crisis and every ecstasy.” A thought to hold on to as we read. “Poyem” carries perhaps an echo of “payim” from 1 Samuel 13: 21-23 where it represents two thirds of a silver shekel, the cost of sword-sharpening. Poetry, and keen speech itself, have a price? At the same time, Atkins is alive to the sheer j-oy of his art, including its significance for meditation. There’s an underlying awareness of what poetry can achieve through its own self-examination, and a potential for ecstasy as well as crisis in many of his poems. This one is ultimately a demonstration of the triumph of argument. Instructions are essential to both digital communications and spiritual exercises, but the result of the proposed 28, we’re told at once, is “non-mastery”. That’s reassuring. The satirical emphasis throughout the poem falls on the commands and the promised reward, but the couplets suggest some profound logical investigation, as well as being funny. Even the first and simplest stimulates the brain-cells with its double-take double negative: “Click here for 29 reasons / you are not not Mark Ruffalo.” Ethical and mystical notes enhance the flavour of stanza three. “Click next to receive yourself as a coupon. / Click Play Now to become forever.” The results of the two clicks seem antithetical at a first glance, but both may represent forms of hubris, one material, one spiritual. I mentioned the aphorism earlier: conjuring aphorisms is one of the skills Atkins has brilliantly not not mastered. Poetry likes them, readers love them, at least when they’re not glib or otherwise unearned. There’s an underlying moral seriousness to their playful deployment by Atkins, when they are playful. Sometimes, of course, they’re simply serious: “Each second you give to thinking // will be matched by 30 minutes / of callousness, regret, and avoidance.” The poem is a fine, bright-witted balancing act. Political anger is evident in the vision of a plague of digitised consumerist ephemera that eventually annihilates conscience. Even when cynicism is overcome, the result is (you) “make millions in emerging emotional markets”. There is some sad wisdom about mavericks in stanzas 11 and 12. Then the mood lightens, as challenge and discussion take over. The final “nu” is a shrug and a saving grace. • Zohar Atkins is the founding director of Etz Hasadeh, “a programme for seekers that uses poetry, philosophy, and meditation to illuminate texts and ideas from Jewish tradition”, and a David Hartman Fellow at the Shalom Hartman Institute of North America.
